review.title: Solving Hybrid Influence Diagrams with Deterministic Variables
review.abstract: We describe a framework and an algorithm for solving hybrid influence diagrams with discrete, continuous, and deterministic chance variables, and discrete and continuous decision variables. A continuous chance variable in an influence diagram is said to be deterministic if its conditional distributions have zero variances. The solution algorithm is an extension of Shenoy's fusion algorithm for discrete influence diagrams. We describe an extended Shenoy-Shafer architecture for propagation of discrete, continuous, and utility potentials in hybrid influence diagrams that include deterministic chance variables. The algorithm and framework are illustrated by solving two small examples.

sections.text: We describe a framework and algorithm for solving hybrid influence diagrams with discrete, continuous, and deterministic random variables, as well as discrete and continuous decision variables. A continuous random variable in an influence diagram is considered deterministic if its conditional distributions have zero variances.The solution algorithm is an extension of Shenoy's fusion algorithm for discrete influence diagrams. We describe an advanced Shenoy shafer architecture for spreading discrete, continuous, and useful potentials in hybrid influence diagrams that include deterministic random variables. The algorithm and framework are illustrated by solving two small examples.

sections.heading: 4 Two Examples
sections.text: In this section, we illustrate our algorithm for solving hybrid influence diagrams with deterministic variables by solving two problems: The first problem is called Entrepreneur's Problem [7] and has continuous random and deterministic variables, a continuous decision variable, and an unfactorial utility function. The second problem is an American put option [2]. This problem has continuous random variables, discrete decision variables with continuous random predecessors, and an additive factorization of the common utility function.

sections.heading: 5 Summary and Discussion
sections.text: The advanced Shenoy shafer architecture for drawing conclusions in hybrid Bayes networks has been extended to include decision variables and utility functions. Two main problems in solving hybrid IDs are the marginalization of continuous random variables and the marginalization of continuous decision variables. For decision problems that do not involve divisions, one solution is to approximate PDFs with MOP functions. MOP functions are closed by multiplication, addition, integration and differentiation; they are not closed by divisions. MOP approximations could be used to mitigate the problems associated with the marginalization of continuous and decision variables.
